awd_titl_txt: Using metacognitive biases to induce curiosity and improve learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Learners are more engaged when curious. They are less likely to mind wander; and they are more likely to seek answers, to be attentive and ready to learn, and they actually learn better as evidenced through both brain and behavioral outcomes.  However, little is known about either the neural basis of curiosity, or ways to induce it.  This project proposes that curiosity is a metacognitive state consisting of feelings that people almost know the answer to the object of curiosity.  This project proposes a series of experiments that investigate both cognitive/behavioral and brain responses. It tests the novel hypothesis that curiosity can be induced by manipulations that alter metacognitive processes, with favorable consequences for learning. Understanding the scientific basis of curiosity will have broad practical and educational implications for increasing students' learning and their desire to learn. 

Past work on curiosity is largely correlational, and often confounds a priori knowledge with feelings of curiosity. In contrast, the experiments in this project induce curiosity via manipulations that alter metacognitive states. Behavioral and electrophysiological experiments, will investigate the impact of curiosity on attention and learning. In these experiments, participants will be exposed to computer-controlled learning scenarios where curiosity is manipulated via priming, fluency, multitasking, divided attention or inhibitory retrieval cuing. Dependent variables include reaction and study times, recall scores, and event-related potentials, as well as ratings of curiosity, confidence, and mind wandering. Curiosity will be manipulated using methods known to influence metacognitive processes. The electrophysiological studies investigating neural processes will allow use of mediational models to evaluate the role of distinct behavioral and brain components related to curiosity. These experiments will disentangle learning attributable to a priori knowledge versus those attributable to curiosity states. This project will help us to understand foundational neural and behavioral processes underlying curiosity-related learning and reward in learning, and the role of metacognition.  There is potential to develop practical methods for systematically inducing curiosity which can be applied to classroom and other settings to enhance learning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
People are highly attentive when they are curious, and their learning is enhanced.  Accordingly, the state of curiosity has far-reaching consequences for education, and has become a prime target for rigorous scientific investigation, though one that has emerged only relatively recently.

            Intellectual merit.  In this project, it was proposed that people are maximally curious when they are grappling with material with which they have considerable familiarity but have not quite fully mastered, that is, when they are in their own Region of Proximal Learning (RPL). The boundary between 'fully knowing' and 'almost knowing' is crucial, though, and it can be both shifting and fuzzy. Once an answer is definitive, curiosity is quenched. As part of the present project, a sequence of eleven inter-related experiments was conducted.  They charted the relation between people's states of knowledge, both as given by their metacognitive confidence judgments, and by the nature and clarity of the feedback that was presented to them, in a question-answering situation in which specific verbal knowledge was sought. These experiments provided strong support for the RPL conceptualization of curiosity.      

Second, we discovered a previously unreported brain correlate of curiosity. As noted above, the RPL model indicates that curiosity increases up to the point at which the answer is known and then drops off precipitously. The tip-of-the-tongue state is characterized by the feeling that the answer is 'almost known' and, as such, is the quintessential RPL curiosity case.  Our own past research has shown that people are more than twice as curious to know the answer when they are in a tip-of-the-tongue state than when they are not. Because people can readily report being in ta tip-of-the-tongue state, it is ideal for investigating the neural correlates of curiosity. Using EEG, we conducted a spectral analysis of the time period just before resolving feedback was presented--while people were still in a state of curiosity. Results indicated that when the individual was in this state, alpha suppression--which in other research is associated with enhanced focal attention--was in evidence. The experiment showed that alpha expression, during this same time period, was associated with the feeling of Not Knowing, indicating a more discursive state. Both alpha and alpha suppression were observed broadly across centro-parietal scalp electrodes and disappeared immediately upon presentation of the resolving feedback.

The third main finding was that curiosity is intrinsically driven rather than being responsive to extrinsic reward. Past research by other investigators has suggested that when people are curious they will wait to get an answer. This result was interpreted as support for an extrinsic reinforcement learning (RL) view of curiosity and as indicating that people would endure an aversive (and essentially passive) wait in order to be given the valuable and rewarding answer. We proposed an alternative 'need for agency' view which holds that people are motivated to obtain the answer by their own efforts, rather than being given it by an external agent. But engaging that effort may take some time.  Three experiments showed that people spontaneously 'waited' longer to request an answer that they could access at any time when they were curious, presumably, in order to try to get it themselves rather than have it merely given to them.  Furthermore, rather than requesting the answer itself (which, by the RL view would produce the maximum reward) in all three experiments, people asked for partial information in the form of hints, when curious. Such active hint seeking predicted later recall. The  intrinsic motivation inherent in the 'need for agency'  view of curiosity was supported by all three experiments. 

Broader impacts.  (1) This research has consequences for educational practice.  The results underline the need to titrate the level of difficulty of the to-be-learned materials to the individual learner, so that the challenges the learner faces are neither so ostensibly trivial and inconsequential that boredom ensues nor so difficult and insurmountable that the learner is overwhelmed and gives up. If people perceive that they already know the answers, their curiosity is not incited, and little learning occurs. But materials that are too difficult and far removed from people's schemata—resulting in their being unable to understand or appreciate their significance—also fail to evoke their curiosity.  The results also suggest that the pleasure associated with curiosity is related to the individual's own agency and from achieving the answer themself, rather than from some extrinsic reward value of the answer.  It follows that passively providing  people with  answers, when they are curious, may backfire--thwarting rather than inspiring curiosity and pleasure in learning. 

(2) The discovery that alpha suppression is a brain correlate of the state of curiosity may have potential as a diagnostic biomarker.
